metadata.titleEn: Human Activity Parameters at Qilian Mountain Area from 1985 to 2019(V2.0)
metadata.description: This data set includes the distribution products of 30 m cultivated land and construction land in Qilian mountain area from 1985 to 2019. The product comes from the land cover classification products of 30m in Qilian mountain area from 1985 to 2019. NDVI products, light data products, DEM products and SAR data of sentry 1 are used in the production of the products. The total accuracy of the product is better than 85%. Among them,  the peoducts from 1985-2015 have a 5 year- time resolution, and the other products have a 1 year - time resolution.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. In addition, the classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary and are hardly suited for land-process modeling and applications at a river basin scale. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
methods: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method. Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: The confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classification accuracy, showing an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the HRB, which is quite higher than previous approaches. Furthermore, a ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

background: It is very difficult to have remote sensing data with both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency; thus, two categories of land-use mapping methodology have been developed separately for coarser resolution and finer resolution data. Land use and land cover are the key factors for understanding the interactions between global changes and human activities, such as social, economic, and cultural activities. Moreover, it is one of the key parameters of land process modeling, and more accurate land use and land cover data will improve the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models. Consequently, land use and land cover data are now widely used in many kinds of researches, such as biodiversity, carbon cycle, public health, crop yield estimation, urban sprawl, forest monitoring, and so on. Since land cover/use can be retrieved straightforwardly from remote sensing, many land cover/use mapping methods using remotely sensed data have been developed for the purposes of regional or global applications.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using the time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.
dataset: The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm). The time series data are composed of one dataset per month, so this time series of data can depict the variation of typical land surface.
findings: The overall accuracy for classification result using the time series of HJ-1/CCD data is 96.76% and the Kappa coefficient is 0.9423; the corresponding overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient for classification result using single Hj-1/CCD data are 87.59% and 0.8296 respectively. Compared with the classification result from single Hj-1/CCD data, the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is more than 10% and the Kappa coefficient is more than 0.1. The overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data are 83.78% and 0.8165 respectively; those using single HJ-1/CCD data are 70.82% and 0.665 respectively. It is similar to the comparison in the Dahuofang area that the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is also 10% higher and Kappa coefficient is also 0.1 higher than that of classification result using single HJ-1/CCD data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that improves land cover mapping accuracy using remotely sensed data?
Example.Answer: One example is utilizing the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data to develop a method for finer resolution land cover mapping, which involves using time series data composed of one dataset per month to depict land surface variations. This approach significantly improves land cover mapping accuracy as demonstrated in regions like the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in land-cover classification using optical remotely sensed imagery?
Example.Answer: A common challenge is the high uncertainty in land-cover classification, particularly between cropland and grassland categories, as well as in dryland systems among shrub, grassland, and forest categories due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. This challenge is especially prevalent in arid regions such as the HRB.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for land cover classification in the context of eco-hydrological modeling?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used is the HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application, which is utilized in combination with Landsat TM/ETM+ and MODIS data for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution to improve eco-hydrological modeling accuracy.

Feature Specification.Answer: remote-sensing data, Landsat/TM, HJ-1/CCD, MODIS, VHSR, image-to-image registration, DN values to TOA radiance, removing atmospheric effects, surface reflectance, time series mosaics

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of remote-sensing data influence the accuracy of land cover mapping?
Feature Specification.Answer: spatial resolution, temporal frequency, geometric qualities, radiometric qualities, use of multiple classifiers, multisource data

Definition.Question: What does 'land-cover dataset' mean in the context of eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling?
Definition.Answer: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling, as they allow for land-cover mapping using remote sensing, which can serve as a substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. These datasets are based on satellite sensors and vary due to differences in data quality, classification approaches, and their alignment with Earth System Model requirements.

Definition.Question: What is a 'mosaic' in the context of remote sensing imagery for land-cover mapping?
Definition.Answer: A mosaic in the context of remote sensing imagery refers to the process of using imagery from sources such as Landsat/TM to create a base image, which is then used for automatic correction of other images like HJ-1/CCD through image-to-image registration. This process helps in producing a time series of mosaics for consistent land-cover mapping over a specified region.

Definition.Question: What does 'time series HJ-1/CCD data' mean for finer resolution land cover mapping?
Definition.Answer: Time series HJ-1/CCD data refers to a dataset composed of multiple images captured over different times, typically one per month, which allows for detailed depiction of land surface variations. This approach significantly enhances the accuracy of land cover mapping by utilizing the temporal and spatial advantages of the HJ-1/CCD satellite constellation.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in computational load and usability challenges between using time series data versus single-time data for land cover mapping?
Comparison.Answer: Time series data significantly increase computational load compared to single-time data, due to the greater volume of data processed. Although the time series approach enhances mapping accuracy, the geometric and radiometric qualities of some data, like HJ-1/CCD, can lower usability and pose additional challenges.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the development of a more detailed land cover dataset impact the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models?
Interpretation.Answer: The development of a more detailed land cover dataset can significantly enhance the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models by providing precise input parameters. This improvement is crucial for modeling interactions between land use changes and environmental processes, thereby reducing errors and increasing the reliability of model predictions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variability in classification accuracies of land-cover datasets, particularly in river basin areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in classification accuracies is due to differences in data quality and properties, absence of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. In river basin areas, the highest uncertainty often arises from classifying cropland and grassland categories and dryland systems among shrub, grassland, and forest categories.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do certain land-cover datasets fail to meet the requirements of Earth System Models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Land-cover datasets often fail to meet the requirements of Earth System Models because they cannot directly map the concept of Plant Functional Types (PFTs), whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions used in these models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the challenges in using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping include increased computational loading due to the volume of data and the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data, which lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its application.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the temporal frequency of data collection from HJ-1/CCD satellites affect the quality and usability of land cover mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of time series HJ-1/CCD data, which provides monthly datasets, greatly enhances the accuracy of land cover mapping. Despite challenges related to increased computational load and the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data, this approach leads to a marked improvement in classification accuracy, achieving over 95% in some areas. The temporal advantage allows for better depiction of land surface variations, which significantly enhances classification results compared to single-date data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of relying on optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying solely on optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification in arid regions can lead to high uncertainty and classification errors, particularly between categories like cropland, grassland, shrub, and forest. These inaccuracies are due to variations in the minimum threshold required for forest cover and affect eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, potentially causing significant errors or modeling failures.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of employing multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for mapping land cover with fine spatial resolution?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective is to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling by providing more detailed and accurate categories of crop/vegetation, which can address the uncertainties in land-cover classification, especially in arid regions like the HRB.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a method for finer resolution land cover mapping using time series data from HJ-1/CCD?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because it takes advantage of the spatiotemporal capabilities of HJ-1/CCD data to significantly enhance the accuracy of land cover mapping, which is crucial for understanding interactions between global changes and human activities, and for improving ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind using a mosaic of Landsat/TM imagery as a base image for land cover classification?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale is to use the mosaic of Landsat/TM imagery as a reference for automatically correcting and preprocessing HJ-1/CCD images, facilitating the creation of time series mosaics that improve the accuracy of classification and reduce uncertainties in land-cover datasets, particularly in arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the accuracy of land-cover classification when using multisource remotely sensed data for mapping eco-hydrological processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A comprehensive method is developed for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands. This involves creating a mosaic of the study area using Landsat/TM imagery and using this as a base image for automatic corrections through image-to-image registration. The preprocessing includes converting DN values to TOA radiance, removing atmospheric effects to obtain surface reflectance, and constructing time series mosaics from HJ-1/CCD data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the effective integration of multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for enhanced land cover mapping accuracy?
Enablement.Answer: A comprehensive method is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do advancements in atmospheric correction techniques enable more accurate surface reflectance retrieval from remote sensing images?
Enablement.Answer: Removing atmospheric effects from remote-sensing images through correction techniques enables obtaining surface reflectance, which is crucial for accurate land cover classification and mapping.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant variability in land-cover dataset classification for eco-hydrological modeling?
Expectation.Answer: There is significant variability in land-cover dataset classification due to differences in data quality and properties, lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. This variability can result in high uncertainty, particularly in classifying cropland and grassland categories and dryland systems among shrub, grassland, and forest categories.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when using remote sensing data with high spatial resolution for land cover mapping?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges with high spatial resolution remote sensing data for land cover mapping include the dramatic increase in computation load due to large data volume and the potential reduction in usability caused by not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of certain data sources like HJ-1/CCD.

Expectation.Question: Why is it difficult to directly map plant functional types using remote-sensing land-cover datasets?
Expectation.Answer: It is difficult to directly map plant functional types using remote-sensing land-cover datasets because the concept of plant functional types involves traits that are a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions which cannot be easily captured using remote-sensing techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the data collection methods used to enhance the accuracy of land cover mapping in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, which include the use of multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, are effective in improving the accuracy of land cover mapping. These methods address the high uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical imagery, particularly in distinguishing between cropland, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems. The overall classification accuracy achieved is significantly higher than previous approaches, indicating a robust methodology.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced in using remote sensing data for land use and land cover mapping, particularly in terms of data quality and computational demands?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in using remote sensing data for land use and land cover mapping are significant. They include the high computational demands due to the use of large datasets and the issues with the geometric and radiometric qualities of certain satellite data, such as HJ-1/CCD. These factors can lower usability and increase the difficulty of accurately mapping land cover. Despite these challenges, the use of advanced data collection methods has resulted in high mapping accuracy, demonstrating the potential to overcome these obstacles.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the prospects for utilizing time series data in improving the accuracy of land cover classification?
Judgmental.Answer: The utilization of time series data holds promising prospects for improving the accuracy of land cover classification. The time series data, especially from sources like HJ-1/CCD, allows for depicting variations in typical land surfaces over time, leading to improved classification accuracy. The increase in overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient when using time series data compared to single datasets suggests that this approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of land cover dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in improving the accuracy of land-use classification in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: In arid regions, the highest uncertainty in land-cover classification occurs frequently between categories like cropland and grassland. This is due to differences in minimum forest cover thresholds, which can lead to large uncertainties and errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why using time series data might enhance land-cover mapping accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: Time series data provide a continuous depiction of land surface changes over time, which enhances mapping accuracy. As seen with the HJ-1/CCD data, the time series approach significantly improved classification accuracy and the Kappa coefficient compared to single data instances.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore how remote sensing data with varying spatial and temporal resolutions can be integrated to enhance land cover mapping accuracy in eco-hydrological research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands can improve land cover mapping accuracy. Specifically, HJ-1/CCD data, Landsat TM/ETM+, and MODIS data are integrated to create detailed land cover maps that cater to eco-hydrological modeling requirements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please examine the methodologies for validating land cover mapping results using very high resolution remote sensing data, focusing on the potential improvements in mapping accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Validation of land cover mapping can be performed using very high resolution remote sensing data from sources like Google Earth. This approach provides high mapping accuracy, with results showing an overall accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% in different study areas, demonstrating significant improvements over single dataset classifications.
